T  echnical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 45513  
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
November 2011 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Sustainable Provincial 
Development Strategy for Guangdong Province 
Focused on Environmental Improvement in Rural 
Areas and Small Cities

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 7 November 2011) 
 
Currency Unit  –  yuan (CNY) 
CNY1.00  =  $0.1575 
$1.00  =  CNY6.3480 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (agriculture and rural 
sector development) 
Theme (subthemes)  –  Environmental sustainability (natural resources 
  conservation, eco-efficiency, environmental policy and 
legislation)  
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high), urban (high), national (low) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Country Director  P. Heytens, People’s Republic of China Resident Mission (PRCM), EARD 
   
Team leader  L. Peng, Senior Economics Officer, PRCM, EARD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2010  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  that  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provide 
Guangdong  Province  (Guangdong)  with  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  help  formulate  a 
sustainable provincial development strategy. The policy advisory technical assistance project for 
Guangdong continues a series of similar projects in diverse provinces in the PRC. ADB first 
approved a TA project of this kind for Hebei Province in 2003. Encouraged by the success of 
that project, the government requested that ADB develop a systematic approach to support 
provincial development strategies. Since then, seven TA projects have been approved covering 
Anhui Province, Chongqing Municipality, Gansu Province, Guizhou Province, Hebei Province, 
Heilongjiang Province, Hubei Province, Hunan Province, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, 
Jiangxi Province, Jilin Province, and Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region.1  
 
2.  An analysis as to the effectiveness of the provincial development strategies concluded 
that the previous TA successfully supported development of provincial strategies.2 Major factors 
contributing to its success included adequate identification of the main development priorities in 
each province, engagement and full ownership of senior provincial officers, and reliance on the 
combined expertise of national and international consultants. Several of the resulting policy 
recommendations have been reflected in socioeconomic development plans at both the central 
and local government levels and implemented in different provinces. For example, several 
policy recommendations under the Hebei provincial development strategy were adopted by 
Hebei  Province,  Beijing  Municipality,  and  Tianjin  Municipality  in  connection  with  plans  to 
improve environmental standards and further boost socioeconomic development.  
 
3.  Dialogue  with  the  Guangdong  provincial  authorities  and  representatives  from  the 
Ministry of Finance clarified the policy and institutional context, as well as priorities for ADB 
support.  Agreement  was  reached  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, costs and financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA.3 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Guangdong has progressed remarkably since the start of the PRC’s economic reform in 
1978,  successfully  transforming  itself  from  an  agriculture  producer  into  a  dynamic 
manufacturing-based economy. The largest economy and most populous province in the PRC 
(with 104 million residents), Guangdong grew at an annual average rate of 13.4% from 1978 to 
2010. The province is also the most urbanized in the PRC, with an urbanization rate of 63.4% in 
2010  against  a  national  average  of  47.5%.  However,  robust  economic  growth  and  rapid 
urbanization have been achieved at the cost of considerable environmental degradation. The 
province  faces  mounting  challenges  in  terms  of  ecological  protection  standards  and 
environmental  safeguards,  which  are  compounded  by  an  accelerating  industrialization  and 
urbanization process unfolding in the northern, western, and eastern areas of the province. 
 
                                                
1
  Xinjiang and Gansu, Hunan and Jiangxi, Heilongjiang and Jilin, Chongqing and Guizhou, and Anhui and Hubei, 
each were combined into single TA projects. 
2  ADB, People’s Republic of China Resident Mission. 2011. Effects and Impacts of ADB’s Technical Assistance on 
Provincial Development Strategies. Beijing.  
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 31 August 2011.

2   
5.  The environmental challenges in Guangdong have been aggravated by rapid expansion 
of emissions and pollutants, as well as the appearance of new pollution sources. For instance, 
polluted soil has become a new source of pollution in the northern, western, and eastern areas 
of  Guangdong.  Such  pollutants,  including  persistent  organic  pollutants,  radioactive  and 
hazardous waste, electronics waste, and sludge, significantly affect people’s daily lives. In 
addition, rural nonpoint source pollution4 has become a major concern after industrial pollution 
and increased household waste. Moreover, environmental degradation and its harmful impact 
on people’s health have increased social tensions in some areas of Guangdong since the 
existing and potential environmental threats have emerged as public concerns and cannot be 
eliminated quickly.  
 
6.  Another challenge relates to the weakness of environmental monitoring mechanisms. A 
number of heavy chemical industries in the province are located in environmentally sensitive 
areas, including densely populated areas and large river basins. Further, most of the operating 
and highly polluting small and medium-sized enterprises are not effectively covered by the 
environmental monitoring system due to inadequate monitoring capacity.  
 
7.  Environmental challenges are particularly pressing in rural areas and small cities,5 due to 
the lack or weakness of basic environmental infrastructure, including solid waste and sewage 
treatment facilities, and lack of adequate regulations for environmental protection. While the 
government’s policy reform agenda is progressively prioritizing and addressing environmental 
issues, the response to date is insufficient to tackle the existing and emerging issues deriving 
from industrial pollution, waste treatment, and nonpoint source pollution in rural areas and small 
cities. To illustrate the point, at present only five counties and cities out of 67 in the province 
have established treatment facilities for solid waste, and merely 44 villages out of 22,105 have 
sewage systems.  
 
8.  As a result, spreading pollution is threatening sustainable socioeconomic development in 
the province. Potential environmental risks call for a more forceful policy and legal framework 
plus better monitoring mechanisms. The TA will focus on improving the ecological environment 
in Guangdong’s rural areas and small cities. Geographically, it will cover the Pearl River Delta, 
the northern region of the province, and its eastern and western counties. Thematically, it will 
address  issues  related  to  improving  energy  efficiency,  reducing  water  and  air  pollution, 
controlling agricultural nonpoint source pollution, managing human and farm livestock wastes, 
protecting rural ecological environments, and improving rural infrastructure.  
 
9.  The TA directly supports ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC (2008–2010) 
and the anticipated priorities of the new partnership strategy now under preparation. Under the 
strategies, ADB seeks, among other objectives, to support government’s efforts to foster a 
cleaner and more sustainable growth process by pilot testing cutting-edge clean energy and 
energy efficiency technologies; developing low-carbon transport systems, particularly in public 
transport; encouraging protection and sustainable use of land, water, and forest resources; 
developing  model  livable  and  low-carbon  cities;  and  promoting  the  development  and 
institutionalization of green financing instruments. 
  
                                                
4
  Nonpoint source pollution refers to both water and air pollution from diffuse sources. Nonpoint source water 
pollution includes such sources as polluted runoff from agricultural areas that drain into a river or wind-borne debris 
blowing  out  to  sea.  Examples  of  nonpoint  source  air  pollution  include  such  sources  as  smokestacks  and 
automobiles.  
5
  Small city refers to towns at or below township administrative level.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact of the TA is an improved environment in the rural areas and small 
cities  of  Guangdong.  The  expected  outcome  is  a  strengthened  policy  framework  for 
environmental protection and environment safeguards in Guangdong’s rural areas and small 
cities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The  TA  will  have  two  main  outputs:  a  comprehensive  report  on  improving  the 
environment in rural areas and small cities in Guangdong completed, as well as at least eight 
policy notes based on the findings and conclusions of the main report prepared. 
 
12.  The comprehensive report will discuss issues related to energy efficiency improvement, 
water  and  air  pollution  reduction,  agricultural  nonpoint  source  pollution  control,  household 
garbage  management,  rural  ecological  environment  protection,  and  rural  infrastructure 
improvement. The report will have at least five chapters covering the following themes: (i) the 
general situation and development trends in the ecological environment in rural areas and small 
cities;  (ii)  common  and  special  environmental  issues  in  the  various  subregions  and  their 
underlying causes; (iii) international good practices and lessons learned in dealing with such 
challenges; (iv) policy recommendations to address the environmental issues in rural areas and 
small cities, including capacity building, environmental awareness, and environmental protection 
incentives; and (v) project concept papers for potential key interventions to strengthen the 
effectiveness of the policy recommendations.  
 
13.  The TA will disseminate research findings and policy suggestions through workshops 
and publications. Key activities include three workshops (inception, midterm review, and final 
draft report review) plus a dissemination conference by June 2013. The final report and policy 
notes will be published for wide distribution.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The Government has requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent.  The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).  
The  Guangdong  provincial  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart  staff,  office  facilities,  resource  persons,  logistical  support,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  The cost estimate is based on engaging expert inputs totaling 32.5 person-months of 
individual consulting services,6 including 1.5 person-months for an international consultant and 
five national consultants for a total of 31 person-months. The international consultant will be a 
rural environment specialist. The national consultants will be (i) a public policy management 
specialist; (ii) an environment specialist; (iii) an agricultural economist; (iv) a rural development 
specialist; and (v) an industrial economist. The consultant team will be responsible for producing

6
  The Guangdong provincial government will hire several consultants through its counterpart financing and plans to 
mobilize them shortly. To ensure all consultants work as a team and produce outputs in a timely manner, the 
executing agency has requested ADB to facilitate efficient consultant recruitment by using individual consultants.

4   
the TA outputs and deliverables in a timely and effective manner, as well as for organizing and 
carrying out all TA activities. The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  The TA’s support for workshops may include costs related to the venue, equipment 
rental, translation,  printing  and  copying,  transportation,  lodging,  logistics  and  administrative 
support, and other expenditures with prior agreement from ADB. In line with standard ADB 
procedures, the TA will not support implementing agency management fees or related costs 
such as staff salaries and allowances or the use of implementing agency resources (such as 
office accommodation), which will be provided as part of the counterpart contribution.  The 
executing and implementing agencies will conduct the workshops and administer the costs. 
ADB  will  establish  an  advance  payment  facility  to  facilitate  efficient  disbursements  of  the 
workshops upon request. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 20 months, from February 2012 to September 2013. 
The  Guangdong  Provincial  Finance  Department  will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  Policy 
Research Office in Guangdong will be the implementing agency. To guide and monitor TA 
implementation, a steering committee, led by the Policy Research Office in Guangdong, will be 
established comprising members from Guangdong Provincial Finance Department, Guangdong 
Provincial  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Guangdong  Provincial  Environment 
Protection Department, Guangdong Provincial Agricultural Department, Guangdong Provincial 
Housing  and  Construction  Department,  Guangdong  Provincial  Economy  and  Information 
Department,  Guangdong  Provincial  Land  Department,  government  think  tanks,  and  other 
government agencies concerned.  
 
18.  The provincial government will set up a project management office, supported by the 
Fiscal Science Research Institute under the Guangdong Provincial Finance Department, to 
administer the TA project and provide logistical support to the consultants. The counterpart staff 
of Guangdong will assist the consultants in carrying out their assignments by providing basic 
statistical  data,  updating  policy  information,  arranging  consultation  meetings  with  local 
government officials, and providing local transportation and office facilities.  
 
19.  The executing agency will provide a suitably furnished office with computers, utilities, and 
telecommunications access (including broadband internet connection), materials, maps, data, 
and documents as required under the TA, and it will cover the cost of office utilities for the 
consultants. The executing agency will also cover remuneration and per diem for counterpart 
staff, designate a TA focal point with strong English speaking and writing skills, and facilitate all 
TA activities to ensure effective implementation of the TA. 
 
20.  In consultation with the executing agency, ADB will recruit national and international 
experts to provide inputs as formal consultants, short-term resource persons, and task-specific 
experts.  The  international  and  national  consultants  (including  resource  persons  and  task-
specific experts) will be selected and engaged on an individual basis by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Individual 
consultants will be chosen based on their academic qualifications and relevant work experience. 
The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement under the TA 
will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time).

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Sustainable Provincial Development 
Strategy for Guangdong Province Focused on Environmental Improvement in Rural Areas and 
Small Cities, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Six individual consultants will be engaged to provide advisory and technical services to 
the Guangdong provincial government. The team of consultants will comprise one international 
consultant and five national consultants. The international consultant will be a rural environment 
specialist. The national consultants will be (i) a public policy management specialist; (ii) an 
environment specialist; (iii) an agricultural economist; (iv) a rural development specialist; and (v) 
an industrial economist. The consultants will carry out their assigned tasks in close cooperation 
with the provincial government agencies.  
 
2.  The consultants need to design and conduct a survey to identify more specifically the 
environmental issues and development constraints in the province’s rural areas and small cities. 
In addition to a literature review, field consultations, and data collection, the consultants need to 
design questionnaires, carry out sampling surveys with assistance from support staff, analyze 
data from the completed questionnaires, and identify the common and special environmental 
issues and development constraints in various subregions. The findings and conclusions of the 
surveys will serve as the most important data source for the technical assistance (TA) study. 
 
3.  The  team  of  consultants  will  produce  a  comprehensive  report  on  improving  the 
ecological environment in Guangdong’s rural areas and small cities. Geographically, the report 
will cover the Pearl River Delta, the province’s northern region, and its eastern and western 
counties. In addition to the specific tasks listed under each consultant, all consultants are 
required to (i) summarize key policy recommendations periodically for distribution to senior 
government officials; (ii) present findings and conclusions at conferences; (iii) propose project 
concept profiles for potential high-priority projects that could be implemented in the short term 
(1–2  years)  and  medium  term  (3–5  years),  and  in  particular  those  suitable  for  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) involvement; (iv) act as resource persons for training programs, as 
required;  and  (v)  share  the  results  of  the  analysis  of  development  constraints  with  the 
designated team of government officials. 
 
4.   The comprehensive report will be written in Chinese and submitted to the provincial 
government and ADB for review in various stages of its maturity, based on the agreed time 
schedule. The final report will be submitted in Chinese and English to the provincial government 
and ADB for dissemination. 
   
A.   Rural Environment Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months) 
 
5.  The  rural  environment  specialist  should  have  a  relevant  degree,  preferably  at 
postgraduate level, in environmental science; rural development; or a related subject. The 
specialist should have a good knowledge of and extensive experience in, technologies for 
addressing the impacts of industrial pollution, reducing agricultural pollution, and promoting rural 
development. Work experience in the People’s Republic of China and proficiency in Chinese 
would be advantages. Responsibilities will include to (i) jointly with the team leader, design the 
TA project; (ii) summarize international best practices in rural environment protection, prepare 
no less than five case studies, and recommend those policies and institutional arrangements 
applicable to Guangdong’s conditions; (iii) identify the key challenges faced by Guangdong in 
protecting the rural environment and recommend countermeasures; and (iv) ensure the quality 
of the executive summary of the reports prepared in English for ADB and the Guangdong 
provincial government.

10  Appendix 3 
B.   National Consultants (5 various, 31 person-months in total) 
 
6.  The public policy management specialist (team leader, 10 person-months) should have 
a relevant degree, preferably at postgraduate level, in public policy management or a related 
subject. He or she should have a good knowledge of, and experience in, formulating public 
policy, including government internal procedures of circulating and approving policy documents, 
cross-agency  consultation  and  coordination,  and  drafting  government  policy  and  legal 
documents. Extensive prior work experience in policy management in Guangdong or in similar 
regions would be an advantage. As team leader and general coordinator with the government, 
the  public  policy  management  specialist  will  be  responsible  to  (i)  jointly  with  the  other 
consultants, refine the project design in line with the TA paper approved by the executing 
agency and ADB; (ii) assign tasks to all team members and set up work schedules; (iii) advise 
team members in undertaking their studies; (iv) act as general coordinator in the policy dialogue 
and consultative discussions with government agencies, including senior government officials; 
(v) supervise team members and ensure the TA implementation milestones are achieved within 
the agreed time schedule; (vi) incorporate written inputs from the other team members and 
finalize the comprehensive report on ecological environmental protection and improvement in 
rural  areas  and  small  cities  in  Guangdong;  and  (vii)  reformat  the  TA’s  final  report  as  a 
government policy document and help clarify any queries raised during circulation and approval.   
 
7.  The rural development specialist (8 person-months) should have a relevant degree in 
rural development or a related subject, preferably at postgraduate level. The specialist should 
have  a  good  knowledge  of,  and  experience  in,  rural  and  social  development.  Favorable 
consideration will be given to those with previous work experience in leading comprehensive 
rural  development  programs  at  various  levels  of  government  and  different  stages  of 
development in Guangdong or similar regions. Responsibilities will include to (i) assist the team 
leader in refining the TA design, in particular regarding general rural development; (ii) jointly with 
the other consultants, design and carry out the sampling surveys, analyze the questionnaire 
responses, and identify the challenges related to rural development and reducing rural pollution; 
(iii) undertake a literature review in the areas assigned; (iv) conduct field consultations with local 
officials in the areas assigned; (v) assess the effectiveness of ongoing government policies on 
rural development and identify the weaknesses for further improvement; and (vi) prepare written 
inputs  on  rural  development,  analyze  the  current  situation  and  trends  in  rural  ecological 
environment protection, and recommend technical solutions for enhancing rural development. 
 
8.  The environment specialist (5 person-months) should have a relevant degree, preferably 
at postgraduate level, in environmental science; rural development; or a related subject. He or 
she should have a good knowledge of, and experience in, technologies for addressing the 
impacts of industrial pollution, reducing agricultural pollution, and dealing with polluted water, air, 
and soil. Responsibilities will include to (i) assist the team leader in refining the TA design, in 
particular  regarding  environmental  protection  and  improvement;  (ii)  jointly  with  the  other 
consultants, design and carry out sampling surveys, analyze the questionnaire responses, and 
identify the environmental issues and development constraints; (iii) undertake a literature review 
in the areas assigned; (iv) conduct field consultations with local officials in the areas assigned; 
(v) assess the effectiveness of ongoing government policies on environmental protection and 
improvement in rural areas and small cities while identifying areas for further improvement; and 
(vi)  prepare  written  inputs  on  balancing  the  rural  ecological  environment  while  minimizing 
adverse effects of household waste, analyze the current situation and development trends of the 
general  rural  ecological  environment,  recommend  technical  solutions  for  improving  the 
ecological environment and general living conditions in rural areas and small cities.

Appendix 3        11 
9.  The  agricultural  economist  (5  person-months)  should  have  a  relevant  degree  in 
agricultural economics or a related subject, preferably at postgraduate level. The agricultural 
economist should have a good knowledge of, and experience in, agricultural production, rural 
development, and agricultural pollution management. Responsibilities will include to (i) assist 
the team leader in refining the TA design, in particular in regard to agricultural development; (ii) 
jointly  with  the  other  consultants,  design  and  carry  out  the  sampling  survey,  analyze  the 
questionnaire responses, and identify the challenges related to agricultural development and 
reducing agricultural pollution; (iii) undertake a literature review in the areas assigned; (iv) 
conduct field consultations with local officials in the areas assigned; (v) assess the effectiveness 
of ongoing government policies on agricultural development and reducing agricultural pollution 
while identifying areas for further improvement; and (vi) prepare written inputs on agricultural 
development and reducing agricultural pollution, analyze the current situation and trends in rural 
ecological environment protection, and recommend technical solutions for improvement and 
reducing agricultural pollution.  
   
10.  The industrial economist (3 person-months) should have a relevant degree in industrial 
economics or a related subject, preferably at postgraduate level. He or she should have a good 
knowledge  of,  and  experience  in,  industrial  upgrading  and  industrial  pollution  control  and 
prevention. Responsibilities will include to (i) assist the team leader in refining the TA design, in 
particular regarding industrial development and pollution control and prevention; (ii) jointly with 
the other consultants, design and carry out the sampling survey, analyze the questionnaire 
responses, and identify the challenges related to industrial upgrading and reducing industrial 
pollution; (iii) undertake a literature review in the areas assigned; (iv) conduct field consultations 
with local officials in the areas assigned; (v) assess the effectiveness of ongoing government 
policies on industrial development and reducing industrial pollution while identifying weaknesses 
for further improvement; and (vi) prepare written inputs on industrial development and reducing 
industrial pollution, analyze the current situation and trends in rural ecological environment 
protection, and recommend technical solutions for improvement and reducing industrial pollution. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
